page.title: 13Life In Bury 1920's (cont.)
page.content: Bread, coal and the mail were delivered by horse drawn vehicles. Milk was not delivered in bottles. A horse drawn cart came round with a milk churn on it and you filled a jug from the churn. The cattle market was on Wednesdays. Sheep, cows and pigs were herded along the streets from the railway station to the cattle pens. The car park behind Woolworth's was the cattle market. The farm workers had to shout a lot and wave sticks to keep the animals together thruogh the town. Boys liked to help as well. Sometimes an animal broke away and had to be chased through the town. The stalls on the Cornhill and the Buttermarket on Wednesdays and Saturdays stayed open untill 9.00 pm. Mr. B. made sugar rock on his stall. The smell was lovely.
